We've sued to block a new law that allows Medicaid to deny transgender Iowans coverage for gender-affirming surgery.
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

ACLU of Iowa clients Mika Covington and Aiden Vasquez are just trying to get the health care their doctors agree they need, but a new law allows Medicaid to deny them coverage to pay for it â€” just because they are transgender. So we've sued.

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Transgender Iowans are entitled to equal protection of the law, and that includes nondiscrimination in Medicaid.

But state officials continue to ignore the consensus among leading medical associations, like the American Medical Association and American Psychological Association: Gender-affirming surgery is medically necessary and can be life-saving for some transgender people in order to treat their gender dysphoria.

In April, Iowa legislators cruelly passed a law that specifically allows Medicaid to deny coverage of such surgeries. This is despite an Iowa Supreme Court ruling just weeks earlier in favor of ACLU of Iowa clients EerieAnna Good and Carol Ann Beal that held that such policies are discriminatory.

So we're fighting back by filing a lawsuit. Again.

We are determined to challenge discrimination against transgender people on other fronts, too. In February, we had a historic win for Jesse Vroegh, our transgender client who was similarly denied coverage for medically necessary gender-affirming surgery under his employer-provided (rather than Medicaid) insurance.

These are the fights against discrimination the ACLU of Iowa was built to take on. Thank you for supporting and sharing in that work. We couldn't do it without you.

Mark Stringer
Executive Director, ACLU of Iowa
